STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 13, 2022
Karen Southgate
Tuscola County DHHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
RE: License #: CP790201478
Tuscola County DHHS
1365 Cleaver Rd
Caro, MI 48723
Dear Ms. Southgate:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 01/07/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Mark R. Hunter, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
411 Genesee
P.O. Box 5070
Saginaw, MI 48605
(989) 395-2847
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of the three identified independent living youth records reviewed did not include
a contract between the youth and the agency identifying the responsibilities of each
party.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.49 – Page 34 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care provider shall
receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must contain the information
required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or
any successor policies approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly
thereafter, an updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by
the “Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015)
(or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and provided to the
foster care provider.
Two of the three identified independent living youth records reviewed contained
medical passports without any signatures to indicate the youth was given a copy of
the medical passport as required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
3

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
The importance of obtaining required dated signatures on all required documents
within 30 days of the document’s completion was discussed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Documentation related to identifying YAVFC and independent living youth was
discussed.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period for the renewal evaluation completed
12/07/2020. The corrective action plan was approved 12/23/2020. Areas identified
in noncompliance as a part of the renewal evaluation were 324(2)(c) (6), 328(2)(a),
FOM 722-8C, FOM 722-06B, and FOM 722-8E. None of these areas were identified
as repeat noncompliance as a part of this interim evaluation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment report included a review of the effectiveness of
the corrective action plan that was implemented and an ongoing review of program
analysis.
Interviews
Child welfare staff including foster care and certification personnel participated in
entrance and exit conferences with no identified concerns.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
4

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
01/07/2022
________________________________________
Mark R. Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 13, 2022
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
